question: CVR components consist of: 1 Microphone 2 Crash/Fire resistant construction 3 Independent battery 4 A Flight data recorder
explanation:
The Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR) consists of:

  1. Microphone – Captures cockpit sounds, communications, and alarms.
  2. Crash/Fire Resistant Construction – The CVR is housed in a protective casing to withstand impact and fire.

However, the CVR does not have:

  • An independent battery – It relies on aircraft power, but an underwater locator beacon (ULB) has its own battery.
  • A Flight Data Recorder (FDR) – The FDR is a separate unit, though some small aircraft may have a combined CVR/FDR system.
subject: Instruments

question: A GPWS system requires

choices.choice: Aural signals which may be supplemented by visual signals
Aural, tactile and visual signals or a combination thereof

explanation:
The correct answer is:

“Aural signals which may be supplemented by visual signals.”

Explanation:

A Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS) primarily provides aural warnings to alert pilots of potential terrain hazards. However, these warnings are often supplemented by visual signals on cockpit displays, such as warning lights or annunciators.
subject: Instruments

question: An aircraft that weights more than 5,700 kg and was registered after 1 April 1998, the FDR and CVR must record respectively:
explanation:
For an aircraft weighing more than 5,700 kg and registered after 1 April 1998, the Flight Data Recorder (FDR) and Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR) must record:

  • FDR: At least 25 hours of flight data.
  • CVR: At least 2 hours of cockpit voice and audio data.
subject: Instruments

question: An FDR fitted to an aircraft of over 5700kgs after Apr 98 must record for:
explanation:
FDR Carriage Requirements

  1. Mandatory for:

    • Aircraft >5700 kg MTOM (since 1 June 1990)
    • Turbine-powered aircraft ≤5700 kg MTOM with >9 passenger seats (since 1 April 1998)
    • All turbine-powered aircraft >5700 kg MTOM (before 1 June 1990)

  2. Recording Duration:

    • Aircraft >5700 kg MTOM: Minimum 25 hours
    • Aircraft ≤5700 kg MTOM (turbine-powered, >9 seats, post-1 April 1998): Minimum 10 hours

  3. Additional Parameters Requirement:

    • Aircraft >27000 kg MTOM must record extra parameters beyond the basic set.

question: An altitude alerting system must at least be capable of alerting the crew on: 1 Approaching selected altitude. 2 Excessive deviation from selected altitude. 3 Excessive vertical speed. 4 Excessive terrain closure. 5 Abnormal gear/flap combination.
explanation:
An altitude alerting system must at least be capable of alerting the crew on:

✅ 1. Approaching selected altitude
✅ 2. Excessive deviation from selected altitude

These are the primary functions of an altitude alerting system.

Other alerts, such as excessive vertical speed (3), excessive terrain closure (4), and abnormal gear/flap combinations (5), are typically handled by different systems like EGPWS (Enhanced Ground Proximity Warning System) or TAWS (Terrain Awareness and Warning System).

question: Where in the aircraft does JAR require the FDR to be fitted:
explanation:
Flight Data Recorder (FDR) Installation Requirement (JAR Regulations)

The Joint Aviation Requirements (JAR) mandate that the Flight Data Recorder (FDR) must be installed in the rear section of the aircraft.

Reason for Placement:

  • The aft section of the aircraft is less prone to damage in the event of a crash, improving the chances of data survivability.
  • It is positioned away from potential impact zones, such as the nose and wings, which are more vulnerable during accidents.

question: According to JAR OPS when must the CVR on a 50 seat turbo prop a/c begin recording?

choices.choice: From lift off to when the weight on wheels switch is made on landing.
From before the a/c is capable of moving under its own power to after the a/c is no longer capable of moving under its own power.
At commencement of the taxy to turning off the runway.

explanation:
According to JAR-OPS (Joint Aviation Requirements – Operations), a Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR) on a 50-seat turboprop aircraft must start recording before the aircraft is capable of moving under its own power (typically when electrical power is applied) and must continue until the aircraft is no longer capable of moving under its own power (typically after shutdown).

This ensures that all pre-flight, taxi, takeoff, cruise, approach, landing, and post-flight communications and sounds are recorded.
subject: Instruments

question: What does a FDR record when combined with a CVR? 1. Cockpit voice 2. Radio 3. Public addresses from the cockpit 4. Cabin voice
explanation:
When a Flight Data Recorder (FDR) is combined with a Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR), it records both flight data and cockpit audio. The audio recordings typically include:

  1. Cockpit voice – Conversations between pilots and other cockpit sounds
  2. Radio communications – ATC transmissions and responses
  3. Public addresses from the cockpit – Announcements made by pilots over the PA system

However, cabin voice is not typically recorded unless there is a dedicated microphone in the cabin, which is rare. The CVR primarily focuses on flight deck audio.
subject: Instruments

question: The requirement to carry a GPWS concerns aircraft which are, depending on their age, weight and passenger capacity 1. Turbo prop 2. Piston 3. Jet
explanation:
The requirement to carry a Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS) applies to aircraft based on their age, weight, and passenger capacity.

Applicable Aircraft Types:

  1. Turbo prop – Required if above a certain weight or passenger capacity (e.g., >5,700 kg MTOW or more than 9 passenger seats).
  2. Jet – Required for all jet-powered aircraft above a certain weight or passenger capacity.
  3. Piston – Generally not required, unless the aircraft meets specific commercial transport regulations.
subject: Instruments

question: TCAS II obtains information from: 1 Pressure encoding from mode S transponder 2 Radio altimeter 3 Aircraft specific configurations 4 Inertial reference unit (IRU)
explanation:
TCAS II obtains information from:

  1. Pressure encoding from Mode S transponder – Provides altitude data.
  2. Radio altimeter – Helps determine altitude above ground level.
  3. Aircraft-specific configurations – Includes aircraft performance characteristics.
  4. Inertial Reference Unit (IRU) – Provides aircraft position and movement data

question: What is the correct response to a TCAS RA?

choices.choice: Smoothly and immediately follow the climb or descent commands
Request permission to manoeuvre from ATC
Follow ATC instructions as these override TCAS RAs
Turn 900 and smoothly and immediately follow the climb or descent commands

explanation:
1. Traffic Advisory (TA) Actions:

  • Alerts crew to potential collision risk.
  • Begin visual search for conflicting traffic.
  • Prepare to respond if an RA follows.
  • Do not maneuver based on TA alone.
  • If traffic remains a concern, consult ATC.

2. Resolution Advisory (RA) Actions:

  • Immediately initiate the RA maneuver.
  • Adjust flight path, power, and trim accordingly.
  • Non-flying crew should monitor traffic visually.
  • Inform ATC of any deviation ASAP.

3. When to Disregard an RA:

  • Only if visual contact confirms no deviation is needed.
  • If ATC instruction conflicts with an RA, follow the RA (TCAS takes priority)
subject: Instruments

question: The principle that TCAS uses is:
explanation:
Principle of TCAS II

TCAS II (Traffic Collision Avoidance System) operates using the secondary surveillance radar (SSR) principle in an air-to-air role, utilizing standard SSR frequencies:

  • 1030 MHz (Interrogation)
  • 1090 MHz (Reply)

Protective Zones

TCAS II establishes two three-dimensional protective bubbles around the equipped aircraft:

  1. Traffic Advisory (TA) Zone – Provides alerts about nearby traffic.
  2. Resolution Advisory (RA) Zone – Issues vertical maneuver instructions to prevent collision.
subject: Instruments

question: The input to a basic stall warning system are:
explanation:
Basic Stall Warning System

A stall warning system primarily relies on the angle of attack (AoA) as its main input.

  • The AoA is detected using vanes on the wing’s leading edge or other sensing devices.
  • When the aircraft approaches its stall point, the system triggers a warning, alerting the pilot to take corrective action.

note that modern aircraft stall warning would have more inputs so make sure you read the question carefully

question: An aircraft registered after the 1 April 1998 requires a CVR which:

choices.choice: Records the last 2 hours of flight
Records the last 72 hours of flight
Records the last 30 minutes of flight
Records the last 8 hours of flight

explanation:
As per ICAO Annex 6 and FAA/EASA regulations, aircraft registered after April 1, 1998, must be equipped with a Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR) that retains at least the last 2 hours of recorded audio.

Why 2 Hours?

  1. Accident Investigation – The last 2 hours are the most critical for understanding incidents, as most accidents occur during approach, landing, or departure.
  2. Technological Advancements – Earlier CVRs recorded only 30 minutes, but this was extended to 2 hours in modern solid-state recorders for better data retention.
  3. Regulatory Compliance – ICAO, FAA, and EASA mandated this change to improve safety and post-accident analysis.
subject: Instruments

question: Which of the following is a preventative RA?
explanation:
Resolution Advisories

It should be remembered that it is not the job of the ACAS system to maintain standard Air Traffic separation minima. If RAs are responded to smoothly and immediately, then the intended vertical separation varies from 300 to 600 ft (700 above FL410) depending on the Sensitivity Level (SL) which decreases with altitude.

Resolution Advisories come in two forms:

  • Preventative Advisories are situations where no collision risk exists unless a change of level is initiated by either aircraft. The synthetic voice advisory is “Monitor Vertical Speed”.
  • Corrective Advisories are situations where a collision risk exists and a manoeuvre is necessary to avert it. The synthetic voice produces the appropriate command.
subject: Instruments

question: What are the JAR OPS requirements for the CVR to start and stop recording?

choices.choice: From the time when the aircraft is first able to move under its own power until it is no longer able to do so.
From the time the first engine is started and stops 5 minutes after the last engine is shutdown.
From the time when the first engine is started and stops 5 minutes after the APU is shutdown
From the time when the aircraft is first able to move under its own power until 5 minutes after it is no longer able to do so

explanation:
JAR-OPS Requirements for Cockpit Voice Recorder (CVR) Operation

According to JAR-OPS 1.700 (Joint Aviation Requirements – Operations), the CVR must:

1. Automatic Start

  • The CVR must automatically start recording when electrical power is applied to the aircraft.
  • It must remain operational for the entire duration of the flight, including engine start, taxi, takeoff, cruise, landing, and shutdown.

2. Continuous Operation

  • The CVR must continuously record once power is supplied, ensuring that critical flight data is captured at all times.

3. Automatic Stop

  • The CVR must continue recording until electrical power is removed, which usually happens:
    • When the aircraft’s engines are shut down after landing.
    • When the electrical power is manually switched off on the ground.
subject: Instruments
